resources.string: The name of this application. This name is displayed to users. Internally, Android uses package name attribute as a unique identifier of application.

The name of this package. From the Android Manifest tag\'s "name" attribute. The package name serves as a unique identifier for the application. It\'s also the default name for the application process and the default task affinity of an activity.
The name of the process this application should run in. From the "process" attribute or, if not set, the same as package name.
The version number shown to users. The attribute has no other purpose than to be displayed to users. The Version code attribute holds the significant version number used internally.

An internal version number. This number is used only to determine whether one version is more recent than another, with higher numbers indicating more recent versions. This is not the version number shown to users; that number is set by the Version name attribute.
If set tot rue, this application is installed in the device\'s system image.
The application\'s description specified by application developer.

A number designating the Android API Level that the application targets. This attribute informs the system that application is tested against the target version and the system should not enable any compatibility behaviors to maintain app\'s forward-compatibility with the target version. The application is still able to run on older versions (down to Min Sdk Version).
Value of Target SDK attribute resolved to the version of Android

A number designating the minimum Android API Level required for the application to run. The Android system will prevent the user from installing the application if the system\'s API Level is lower than the value specified in this attribute. Google Play uses the this attributes to filter app from devices that do not meet it\'s platform version requirements.
Value of Min SDK attribute resolved to the version of Android
Android applications are distributed as an Android Application Packages (APK). Once installed, APK file is saved in storage. This attribute represents path to APK file of given application.
Full path to the default directory assigned to the package for its persistent data.

The default install location for the application. The following values are accepted:

Internal Only - The application must be installed on the internal device storage only. If this is set, the application will never be installed on the external storage. If the internal storage is full, then the system will not install the application. This is also the default behavior. 

Auto - The application may be installed on the external storage, but the system will install the application on the internal storage by default. If the internal storage is full, then the system will install it on the external storage. Once installed, the user can move the application to either internal or external storage through the system settings. 

Prefer External - The application prefers to be installed on the external storage (SD card). There is no guarantee that the system will honor this request. The application might be installed on internal storage if the external media is unavailable or full. Once installed, the user can move the application to either internal or external storage through the system settings.
The time at which the app was first installed.
The time at which the app was last updated.
The signature algorithm name for the certificate signature algorithm. An example is the string \"SHA256withRSA\"
Start of validity period of the certificate.
End of validity period of the certificate.
MD5 hash of public key of the certificate.

Serial Number value from the certificate. The serial number is an integer assigned by the certification authority to each certificate. It must be unique for each certificate issued by a given CA (i.e., the issuer name and serial number identify a unique certificate).
Name of issuer of the certificate
Name of organization of issuer of the certificate
Country of issuer of the certificate
Name of subject of the certificate
Name of organization of subject of the certificate
Country of subject of the certificate

Total number of drawables contained in APK file. This includes all files in /res/drawable directory. Files from support libraries are included as well. If drawable is provided multiple times, e.g. in different resolution, it is counted multiple times.

Number of logically unique drawables contained in APK file. Files from support libraries are included as well. If drawable is provided multiple times, e.g. in different resolution, it is counted only once.
Number of png drawables included in APK file.

Number of nine patch (9.png) drawables included in APK file. A nine patch drawable graphic is a stretchable bitmap image that you can use as the background of a view. Android automatically resizes the graphic to accommodate the contents of the view.
Number of jpg drawables included in APK file.
Number of gif drawables included in APK file.
Number of xml drawables included in APK file. Xml drawables are marker files containing data about shapes etc.
Number of drawables optimized for screens with low pixel density ~120dpi
Number of drawables optimized for screens with medium pixel density ~160dpi
Number of drawables optimized for screens with high pixel density ~240dpi
Number of drawables optimized for screens with extra high pixel density ~320dpi
Number of drawables optimized for screens with extra extra high pixel density ~480dpi
Number of drawables optimized for screens with extra extra extra high pixel density ~640dpi
Number of drawables for all densities. These are density-independent resources. The system does not scale resources tagged with this qualifier, regardless of the current screen\'s density.

Resources for screens somewhere between mdpi and hdpi; approximately 213dpi. This is not considered a "primary" density group. It is mostly intended for televisions and most apps shouldn\'t need it—providing mdpi and hdpi resources is sufficient for most apps and the system will scale them as appropriate.

Total number of layouts contained in APK file. This includes all files in /res/layouts directory. Files from support libraries are included as well. If layout is provided multiple times, e.g. one layout name for two layouts - one in landscape and other in portrait modus, it is counted multiple times.

Number of logically unique layouts contained in APK file. Files from support libraries are included as well. If layout is provided multiple times, e.g. one layout name for two layouts - one in landscape and other in portrait modus, it is counted only once.
Optional name of a permission required to be able to access this Service.
If true, service may be called by another activity.
The service will automatically be stopped by the system if the user removes a task that is rooted in one of the application\'s activities.
Single instance of the service will run for all users on the device.
The service will run in its own isolated process.
The service can be bound and run in the calling application\'s package, rather than the package in which it is declared.
Authorities that identify data offered by the content provider. Data offered by this content provider are published under this identification.
Optional permission required for read-only access this content provider.
Optional permission required for read/write access this content provider.

Whether the content provider is available for other applications to use:

true: The provider is available to other applications. Any application can use the provider's content URI to access it, subject to the permissions specified for the provider. 

false: The provider is not available to other applications. Set android:exported="false" to limit access to the provider to your applications. Only applications that have the same user ID (UID) as the provider will have access to it.

The name of a permission that broadcasters must have to send a message to the broadcast receiver. If this attribute is not set, the permission set by the application element\'s permission attribute applies to the broadcast receiver. If neither attribute is set, the receiver is not protected by a permission.

Whether or not the broadcast receiver can receive messages from sources outside its application - \"yes\" if it can, and \"no\" if not. If no, the only messages the broadcast receiver can receive are those sent by components of the same application or applications with the same user ID.
